ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Laser-assisted generation of gold nanoparticles and nanostructures in liquid and their plasmonic luminescence

Affiliation.OrgName: Wave Research Center of AM Prokhorov General Physics Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences
P.N. Lebedev Physical Institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Nanoparticles (NPs) and surface nanostructures (NS) are produced via laser ablation of a bulk gold target in liquid using second harmonics of 10 ps Nd:YAG laser (532 nm) with repetition rate of 50 kHz. The morphology and plasmon photoluminescence (PL) properties of obtained nanoscale objects are described. Transmission electron microscopy and field emission scanning electron microscopy are used for morphology characterization of NPs and NS, respectively. Plasmon PL of both gold NPs and NS is experimentally studied using the third harmonics of the Nd:YAG picosecond laser (355 nm) as a pump. The wavelength of intensity maximum of PL of Au NPs colloidal solution virtually coincides with the position of Au NPs plasmon absorption peak. Real-time excitation of both plasmon PL and Raman scattering of surrounding liquid by picosecond laser pulses in aqueous colloidal solution is also investigated. The efficient cross section of plasmon PL of Au NPs colloid is evaluated using Raman scattering of water as a comparative parameter. The results are in good agreement with values obtained in previous works. Plasmon PL from self-organized NS on the Au surface produced via laser ablation is observed for the first time. Its spectrum is compared to PL spectra of both aqueous colloidal solutions of NPs and of NPs deposited on a Si wafer. The obtained experimental data are discussed with reference to the band structure of bulk Au.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Plasmon luminescence of noble metals nanoparticles (NPs) is extensively studied nowadays. After the pioneering work of Mooradian [1], dedicated to plasmon photoluminescence (PL) from bulk metals and several papers by Boyd [2, 3] researches dedicated to luminescence of nanosized materials were considered in a number of papers. Gold NPs are widely used as an object of investigation due to their chemical properties and the wavelength of plasmon resonance of gold, which lies in visible range around 520 nm. Such photoluminescent nanosized objects can enhance properties of conventional devices such as light-emitting diodes [4] or light sensors [5, 6]. Also, they are promising to be used in fabrication of cutting-edge photonic objects and devices, for example, quantum dots [7] and spasers [8, 9].

Despite the popularity of the investigation of NPs PL properties, there is a relatively small amount of works dedicated to plasmon PL of surface nanostructures (NS). PL considered in [1] can be ascribed to the presence of nanoprotrusions and defects of sample surface. PL from both gold films and NPs is investigated by the authors of [10]. Nevertheless, to the best of our knowledge, there are no works concerning PL of gold surface NS.

In our work, we investigate plasmon PL from gold NPs during the process of laser ablation. PL from both NPs colloidal solution and NPs deposited on Si wafer is investigated. Also, luminescence from self-organized Au NS produced via ablation of a bulk Au target in water is observed and compared with luminescence from NPs. The NS considered in present work represent a type of surface structures whose morphology and formation mechanisms significantly differ from the well-known laser-induced periodic surface structures [11]. Similar NS generated on surface of silver, gold and other metals upon their laser ablation in liquids were studied earlier [12–14]. Also this type of structures was produced on surface of silicon [15].

The third harmonics of a Nd:YAG laser is used as a pump for PL excitation. Its photon energy (3.48 eV) is enough to excite the electrons from the valence band of Au to its conduction band. In excited state, the electrons firstly relax to the bottom of the band and then return via non-radiative transition to the d-band. The residue of their energy is sufficient to excite the collective oscillations of the valence electrons of d-band [16]. In their mathematical simulation Boyd and others [2, 3] supposed Au surface to have the morphology of an array of hemispheroids with tens to hundreds of nanometers in diameter. The experimental data presented in [2, 3] deal with the observation of enhanced second-harmonic generation from such surfaces. To this moment, there is no experimental data on observation of PL from on gold surface with well-defined NS. In the present work, these NS are generated by laser ablation of a bulk Au target in water, and their luminescence is experimentally investigated.

Section1.Heading: Experimental setup
Section1.Para: Gold NPs were obtained via laser ablation of a bulk Au target in liquid environment. Experimental details on laser generation of NPs are described elsewhere [17, 18]. Laser beam was focused on a bulk gold target immersed in working liquid using a converging lens with focal length of 5 cm. Reverse osmosis water was used as a working liquid. During the generation of nanosized gold the ablation was performed in scanning regime using the X–Y coordinate stage. The scanning speed was of 50 mm/s. In case of NS generation the area of 6 × 6 mm2 on the surface of gold target was covered with NS of uniform morphology. The size of laser spot on the target was of 100 μm.

Duetto picosecond Nd:YAG laser system (Time–Bandwidth) was used as a source of laser radiation. It features 10 ps pulses with repetition rate of 50 kHz. The second harmonics of YAG laser was used for generation of NPs (100 μJ pulse energy and up to 7 W average power at wavelength of 532 nm) while the third harmonics was used as pump for luminescence (50 μJ and up to 3.5 W at 355 nm, respectively).

The experimental study consisted of two stages. At the first step, Au NPs and NS were generated via laser ablation of gold target immersed into water (Fig. 1) [17, 18]. Then PL properties of obtained nanosized gold were analyzed with third harmonics of Nd:YAG laser as a pump (see Fig. 2). Laser fluence on the target was of about 1 J/cm2 in case of NS generation, while the number of pulses was of 50 per point. In case of NPs generation laser fluence was of 1.5 J/cm2 with the same number of pulses per point. Laser fluence was evaluated using the size of heat-affected zone on the gold target.
Fig. 1
Experimental setup on nanosized gold generation. 1 Laser source, 2 laser beam, 3 45° mirror, 4 converging lens, 5 cell filled with working liquid, 6 lens focal spot, 7 gold target
Fig. 2
Experimental setup on emission spectra acquisition. 1 Laser source, 2 laser beam, 3 45° mirror, 4 quartz cell with investigated colloidal solution, 5 gold target, 6 optic fiber, 7 spectrometer

The morphology of obtained NPs was characterized via transmission electron microscope (TEM) with electron beam energy of 200 keV. To this end, colloidal solution was evaporated on copper grid coated with a carbon membrane.

The gold surface was studied using a SII Nanopics 2000 atomic force microscope (AFM) in the contact mode and Jeol JSM7610F field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM). The colloidal solution of Au NPs deposited on a silicon wafer via evaporation of the obtained colloidal solution was also studied using AFM in a damping mode.

An ocean optics fiber fluorimeter was used for acquisition of luminescence spectra and ocean optics spectrometer for acquisition of extinction spectra, respectively. The third harmonics of Duetto laser was used as a source for excitation of PL. The experimental setup shown in Fig. 2 allowed observation of either PL spectrum of the colloidal solution and of its luminescence just above the target.
Luminescence properties of nanosized gold were also studied using Raman spectrometer based on a cw Argon ion laser. The 457.9 nm wavelength was used as a pump.

Section2.Heading: Morphology
Section2.Para: Laser ablation of a gold target in liquid leads to generation of colloidal solution of Au NPs. Typically, such colloidal solutions are colored from reddish to bluish, depending on their shape [19]. This coloration of liquid is correlated with absorbance in the visible range of spectra. In this particular case, optical properties of solutions are mostly determined by so-called plasmon resonance of NPs. Mathematical calculations of absorption spectra of various metals NPs were conducted by Creighton and others [20]. Based on the Mie theory, these calculations were applied to the spherical particles with size of 10 nm.

NPs generated via laser ablation in liquids basically have spherical shape with several tens nanometers in diameter (Fig. 3b) with size distribution maximum located at around 10 nm (Fig. 3a). Apart from particles with spherical form some elongated particles can be observed. So, additional absorbance peak corresponding to longitudinal plasmon resonance can be expected [21].
Fig. 3
General TEM view of Au NPs, size distribution of Au NPs is shown on inset (a), detailed TEM view of Au NPs (b)

During the ablation process so-called self-organized NS are formed on the surface of the target [22]. Their size distribution does not typically depend on wavelength of laser radiation [23]. Under certain conditions, microstructures can also be formed on surface of target, namely at sufficient laser fluence and number of pulses [24]. In this work, laser fluence on the surface of gold target exceeded melting threshold of the material [25] while the number of pulses (50, as mentioned above) was enough for the surface morphology to be represented by both types of structures. In Fig. 4a, one can clearly see the presence of NS on the surface of the gold target after laser irradiation. Figure 5 shows the coexistence of both microstructures and NS.
Fig. 4
AFM view. A nanostructured surface of gold target after laser irradiation (a). NPs deposited on Si wafer (b)
Fig. 5
FESEM image of gold target irradiated by Nd:YAG laser with wavelength of 532 nm and pulse duration of 10 ps

Section2.Heading: Optical properties
Section2.Para: Laser ablation of Au target in liquid is accompanied by Raman scattering of the liquid. If laser source with wavelength of 355 nm is used, the Stokes peak of liquid will be situated in visible range. Using the experimental setup described above the spontaneous Raman scattering of water was observed.

Normalized Raman spectrum of water is shown in Fig. 6. The Stokes peak (3,500 cm−1) can be clearly seen [26]. The inset in Fig. 6 shows the linear dependence of 406 nm emission of water on the power of pump radiation. It verifies that the Stokes peak of spontaneous Raman scattering of H2O is observed and not the stimulated one.
Fig. 6
Normalized Raman spectrum of pure H2O. Third harmonics of a Nd:YAG laser with pulse duration of 10 ps at wavelength of 355 nm was used as the pump. Inset shows the dependence of water Raman scattering intensity on the pump radiation power

When dealing with the spectrum of aqueous colloidal solution of gold NPs two emission bands can be clearly seen. One of them (406 nm) still corresponds to Stokes scattering by water mentioned above. The other one (525 nm) is related to plasmon PL of gold [20].

Based on the chart in Fig. 7, we can estimate the efficiency of gold NPs PL compared to Raman scattering of water using their relative integral intensities:
Fig. 7
Normalized emission spectra of aqueous colloidal solution of gold NPs and NS immersed into water. Third harmonics of a Nd:YAG laser with pulse duration of 10 ps at wavelength of 355 nm was used as the pump. Both peaks of NPs and NS are situated around 520–525 nm

= 1.4 × 10−28 [27, 28]. Concentration of gold NPs was estimated on the same basis as in earlier paper [29]. Mass of NPs dispersed in liquid was determined as target mass defect before and after the ablation process. Then the number of particles was determined with the assumption of mean NPs size of 10 nm (see Fig. 3a). The concentration was then evaluated using Eq. 2: 2

Earlier experiments on quantum yield of gold NPs conducted by Gaiduk and others [30] have shown QY = (3.1 ± 1.2) × 10−7 for NPs about 10 nm in diameter. In our experiments, QY =
$$ n_{\text{Au}} \times \sigma_{\text{Au}} $$
n Au
×
σ Au
= 1.43 × 10−5. El-Sayed shows in [31] that QY for spherical NPs of 20 nm in diameter equals to 2 × 10−4 and is much higher for elongated Au NPs. Enhanced plasmon PL observed in our experiments can be assigned to amplification of the laser radiation on nanoentities presented in liquid, either NPs or NS.

PL spectra of gold NS under excitation with a cw Ar ion laser are shown in Fig. 8. It should be noticed that PL can also be observed on non-irradiated surface of gold target adjacent to nanostructured area. This may occur due to the presence of NPs re-deposited on the surface during the ablation. The melting temperature of NPs depends on their size [32], so smaller particles are more probable to re-deposit on the target surface (see Fig. 9).
Fig. 8
Luminescence spectra of nanosized Au. NS on gold target (1), NPs deposited on Si wafer (2), gold target adjacent to nanostructured area (3). 457.9 nm cw Argon laser was used as the pump
Fig. 9
AFM view of Au NPs re-deposited on Au surface during the ablation

Boyd and others [2] showed that the surface relief similar to NS produced via laser ablation can enhance the PL efficiency. The experimental data in our work confirm their hypothesis. While the PL efficiency of a bulk gold is of the order of 10−10–10−9 [1], in our case it rises to the level observable in experimental setup used.

The spectrum of NPs evaporated on Si wafer from colloidal solution differs from the spectrum of gold target. The red shift of maximum can be explained by agglomeration of NPs (Fig. 4b) leading to appearance of longitudinal plasmon resonance [31]. However, spectral position of plasmon resonance can also be strongly dependent on local environment around the NPs. In case of NPs evaporated on Si wafer plasmon oscillations of electrons in NPs are affected by polarization of the substrate. Although the effect of the silicon substrate is not so pronounced as for NPs embedded in dielectric matrix, it can lead to the red shift of PL maximum [33].

The maximum of PL spectrum of gold target adjacent to nanostructured area is narrower and slightly blue-shifted. It is known that in case of NPs such shift of plasmon resonance can occur due to the size reduction of NPs studied [34]. In our case that size effect happens due to the fact that surface morphology is represented either by the initial surface roughness or by re-deposited NPs. Agglomeration of NPs is avoided due to the fact that they are frozen into the substrate material. So, we can deduce that due to the temperature dependence of melting temperature on their size very small Au NPs may stick to the bulk substrate, and PL of these small NPs is blue-shifted compared to larger size.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: The efficient PL of NPs and self-organized NS obtained via laser ablation in liquid was studied. The maximum of luminescence spectrum coincides with the frequency of plasmon resonance of NS. The PL efficiency of colloidal solution of gold NPs was evaluated from the luminescence spectra. The integral intensities of Raman scattering and PL were compared. The value calculated this way (QY = 1.43 × 10−5) is in good agreement with previous data on this subject. PL was also observed on such areas of gold target that were not affected by laser radiation. We explain this by re-deposition of NPs during ablation process and initial roughness of target surface.
